abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural
            Extension Project for Cote d'Ivoire was marginally
            unsatisfactory. The project achieved some of its objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was modest,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was marginally
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, much progress was made in spite of a very
            complicated institutional, financial, and economic
            environment which did not favor adequate project
            implementation and management. Second, the T&V system of
            extension is very efficient as it is tailored to local
            conditions. Third, an effective monitoring and evaluation
            system, with clear objectives, is indispensable for
            efficient management of extension activities. Fourth,
            although women play a major role in food crop production,
            they were not seriously taken into account during project
            implementation. Finally, the efficiency of the T&V
            system is adequate as long as a critical minimum of funding
            is available to enable proper mobility and training of staff.
